summary: The research explores the trend of firms increasingly engaging in environmental lobbying to promote eco-friendly policies, contrasting this with traditional lobbying aimed at reducing regulatory burdens. It investigates the motivations behind this shift, specifically focusing on how product strategy influences lobbying behavior. The findings suggest that firms with a higher intensity of green products are more likely to lobby for environmental causes, as they can adapt to new market regulations more easily than less eco-friendly competitors. Furthermore, these firms can effectively lobby for government incentives and subsidies to enhance their market position. An analysis of the US light vehicle market reveals a positive correlation between the sales of electric vehicles and environmental lobbying efforts, with this relationship being stronger for firms with larger market shares or those from countries with stricter environmental regulations.
